title: Live updates: Israel says it is carrying out strikes on military targets in Iran; blasts heard in Tehran
description: The Israel Defense Forces announced the operation, saying it was in response to “continuous attacks” from Iran.
author: Mikhail Klimentov, Steve Hendrix, Missy Ryan
byline: Mikhail Klimentov, Steve Hendrix, Missy Ryan, Alon Rom, Susannah George, Dan Lamothe, Niha Masih, Joe Snell
excerpt: The Israel Defense Forces announced the operation, saying it was in response to “continuous attacks” from Iran.
text: Israel is carrying out strikes against military targets in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said Friday, calling the strikes a response to “continuous attacks” from Iran. Multiple explosions were heard in the Iranian capital, Tehran’s state media reported. The scale and duration of the attack was not immediately apparent, but an Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified planning, said Israel would not hit Iran’s oil production or nuclear research sites.Live coverage contributors 8Return to menuThe scale and duration of Israel’s attack on Iran was not immediately apparent, but an Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified planning, said Israel would not hit Iran’s oil production or nuclear research sites, considered the targets most likely to provoke yet another escalation in the cycle of attack and counterattack that the two countries have been engaged in for months.Return to menuWp logoThe Israel Defense Forces released a photo of Maj. Gen. Herzi Halevi, who it said was commanding the attack on Iran from the Air Force base in Kirya, in Tel Aviv, alongside Air Force Commander General Tomer Bar. The Israeli prime minister’s office separately released a highly redacted photo of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant sitting at a table, the surface blurred out, during the attack.Iranian media says military bases targeted by Israel, downplays strikesReturn to menuIranian state-run media reported the sound of explosions in western parts of Tehran early Saturday morning. The semiofficial Fars news outlet reported that “a number of military bases” in Iran’s west, south and in Tehran were targeted by Israel.Many broadcasters downplayed the strikes, airing scheduled programming. One news outlet said the sounds of the explosions were Iran’s air defenses.Tasnim news shared a video of the Tehran skyline on social media, writing: “There is no fire or smoke in this scene.”Return to menuThe United States was aware “well in advance” of Israel’s operation to strike Iran, a U.S. official speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters told The Washington Post.Return to menuThe United States was informed beforehand of the Israeli strikes on Iran, a U.S. defense official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters, told The Washington Post. The official said the United States wasn’t involved in the operation.Return to menuWarplanes could be heard in the skies over Jerusalem early Saturday as reports emerged that Israel had launched its attack against Iran. It was not clear whether the aircraft were taking part in the mission against Iranian targets or providing air defense in case of a counterstrike. Israel said it was deploying its full offensive and defensive capabilities.Return to menuA U.S. defense official said Friday night that he was aware of open-source reports of explosions in Iran and looking into them. The official, speaking on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue, said he had no additional information to offer.Return to menuFor weeks, Israeli officials have hinted at an impending military response to Iran’s ballistic missile barrage. On the night of Iran’s Oct. 1 attack on Israel, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Iran had made “a big mistake,” and Israel would “exact a price” from Tehran. About a week later, Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant warned that Israel’s response would be “precise, painful and surprising.”Return to menuNational Security Council spokesman Sean Savett described Israel’s strikes against Iran “as an exercise of self-defense” in retaliation for the barrage of ballistic missiles fired against Israel on Oct. 1. “We would refer you to the Israeli government for more information on their operation,” Savett said.Return to menuIran’s Oct. 1 missile barrage against Israel — which precipitated tonight’s Israeli attack — followed the killing of Hezbollah leader Hasan Nasrallah in Beirut by Israel, and the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran. The two leaders’ deaths made it difficult for Iran to maintain its posture of restraint, wherein it sought to avoid all-out conflict with Israel.Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian framed Iran’s attack as a justifiable response to Israeli escalation in an Oct. 1 post on platform X. “Iran is not a belligerent, but it stands firmly against any threat,” Pezeshkian said. “This is only a fraction of our power. Do not enter into a conflict with Iran.”Return to menuThe Israeli strikes on Iran come on the heels of U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s trip to the region this week. Blinken traveled to Israel, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Kingdom, meeting regional leaders in the latest U.S.-led effort to end the conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon and secure the release of the hostages held by Hamas.Return to menuIn the days after Iran’s Oct. 1 attack on Israel, President Joe Biden said he would not support an Israeli retaliatory strike on Iranian nuclear infrastructure. Separately, he told reporters that he didn’t think Israel should strike Iranian oil fields.Netanyahu told Biden earlier this month that Israel planned to strike military targets in Iran, two officials familiar with the matter told The Washington Post.Return to menuIsrael is striking military targets in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said Friday, amid reports in Iranian state media of explosions across Tehran.“In response to months of continuous attacks from the regime in Iran against the State of Israel – right now the Israel Defense Forces is conducting precise strikes on military targets in Iran,” the IDF said.“The regime in Iran and its proxies in the region have been relentlessly attacking Israel since October 7th,” the Israeli military added. “Like every other sovereign country in the world, the State of Israel has the right and the duty to respond.”Return to menuSirens blared across the Ankawa neighborhood of Irbil, Iraq, beginning around 1:48 a.m. local time and have continued for nearly 30 minutes. There are no signs of missiles darting across from the skies, despite no cloud cover. Residents have gathered on their rooftops to shoot videos.Loudspeakers coming from the military base at Irbil airport blast just one word: “Bunkers.”A timeline of conflict on the Israel-Lebanon border A timeline of conflict on the Israel-Lebanon border Israeli military deaths in Lebanon raise questions over war’s scope Israeli military deaths in Lebanon raise questions over war’s scope Hezbollah is undeterred as Lebanon braces for war with IsraelHezbollah is undeterred as Lebanon braces for war with Israel
html:
• Israel is carrying out strikes against military targets in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said Friday, calling the strikes a response to “continuous attacks” from Iran. Multiple explosions were heard in the Iranian capital, Tehran’s state media reported. The scale and duration of the attack was not immediately apparent, but an Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified planning, said Israel would not hit Iran’s oil production or nuclear research sites.

  • Live coverage contributors 8

  • Return to menu

    The scale and duration of Israel’s attack on Iran was not immediately apparent, but an Israeli official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified planning, said Israel would not hit Iran’s oil production or nuclear research sites, considered the targets most likely to provoke yet another escalation in the cycle of attack and counterattack that the two countries have been engaged in for months.

  • Return to menu

    Wp logo

    The Israel Defense Forces released a photo of Maj. Gen. Herzi Halevi, who it said was commanding the attack on Iran from the Air Force base in Kirya, in Tel Aviv, alongside Air Force Commander General Tomer Bar. The Israeli prime minister’s office separately released a highly redacted photo of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant sitting at a table, the surface blurred out, during the attack.

  • Iranian media says military bases targeted by Israel, downplays strikes

    Return to menu

    Iranian state-run media reported the sound of explosions in western parts of Tehran early Saturday morning. The semiofficial Fars news outlet reported that “a number of military bases” in Iran’s west, south and in Tehran were targeted by Israel.

    Many broadcasters downplayed the strikes, airing scheduled programming. One news outlet said the sounds of the explosions were Iran’s air defenses.

    Tasnim news shared a video of the Tehran skyline on social media, writing: “There is no fire or smoke in this scene.”

  • Return to menu

    The United States was aware “well in advance” of Israel’s operation to strike Iran, a U.S. official speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters told The Washington Post.

  • Return to menu

    The United States was informed beforehand of the Israeli strikes on Iran, a U.S. defense official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters, told The Washington Post. The official said the United States wasn’t involved in the operation.

  • Return to menu

    Warplanes could be heard in the skies over Jerusalem early Saturday as reports emerged that Israel had launched its attack against Iran. It was not clear whether the aircraft were taking part in the mission against Iranian targets or providing air defense in case of a counterstrike. Israel said it was deploying its full offensive and defensive capabilities.

  • Return to menu

    A U.S. defense official said Friday night that he was aware of open-source reports of explosions in Iran and looking into them. The official, speaking on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue, said he had no additional information to offer.

  • Return to menu

    For weeks, Israeli officials have hinted at an impending military response to Iran’s ballistic missile barrage. On the night of Iran’s Oct. 1 attack on Israel, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Iran had made “a big mistake,” and Israel would “exact a price” from Tehran. About a week later, Israeli Defense Minister Yoav Gallant warned that Israel’s response would be “precise, painful and surprising.”

  • Return to menu

    National Security Council spokesman Sean Savett described Israel’s strikes against Iran “as an exercise of self-defense” in retaliation for the barrage of ballistic missiles fired against Israel on Oct. 1. “We would refer you to the Israeli government for more information on their operation,” Savett said.

  • Return to menu

    Iran’s Oct. 1 missile barrage against Israel — which precipitated tonight’s Israeli attack — followed the killing of Hezbollah leader Hasan Nasrallah in Beirut by Israel, and the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran. The two leaders’ deaths made it difficult for Iran to maintain its posture of restraint, wherein it sought to avoid all-out conflict with Israel.

    Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian framed Iran’s attack as a justifiable response to Israeli escalation in an Oct. 1 post on platform X. “Iran is not a belligerent, but it stands firmly against any threat,” Pezeshkian said. “This is only a fraction of our power. Do not enter into a conflict with Iran.”

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli strikes on Iran come on the heels of U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s trip to the region this week. Blinken traveled to Israel, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Kingdom, meeting regional leaders in the latest U.S.-led effort to end the conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon and secure the release of the hostages held by Hamas.

  • Return to menu

    In the days after Iran’s Oct. 1 attack on Israel, President Joe Biden said he would not support an Israeli retaliatory strike on Iranian nuclear infrastructure. Separately, he told reporters that he didn’t think Israel should strike Iranian oil fields.

    Netanyahu told Biden earlier this month that Israel planned to strike military targets in Iran, two officials familiar with the matter told The Washington Post.

  • Return to menu

    Israel is striking military targets in Iran, the Israel Defense Forces said Friday, amid reports in Iranian state media of explosions across Tehran.

    “In response to months of continuous attacks from the regime in Iran against the State of Israel – right now the Israel Defense Forces is conducting precise strikes on military targets in Iran,” the IDF said.

    “The regime in Iran and its proxies in the region have been relentlessly attacking Israel since October 7th,” the Israeli military added. “Like every other sovereign country in the world, the State of Israel has the right and the duty to respond.”

  • Return to menu

    Sirens blared across the Ankawa neighborhood of Irbil, Iraq, beginning around 1:48 a.m. local time and have continued for nearly 30 minutes. There are no signs of missiles darting across from the skies, despite no cloud cover. Residents have gathered on their rooftops to shoot videos.

    Loudspeakers coming from the military base at Irbil airport blast just one word: “Bunkers.”
